question: We sure picked the wrong night to find a cemetery. Let's turn back.
answer: No. It's on a night like this when the best ideas come to mind.

question: But does it have to be in a cemetery?
answer: You wouldn't understand. Seeing a cemetery on a night like this can stir in the mind the best ideas for a good horror story.

question: But there're so many wonderful things to write about, Bob.
answer: Sure there are--and I've tried them all. Plays, love stories, westerns, dog stories. Huh, now there was a good one, that dog story all about--

question: But horror stories! Why all the time horror stories?
answer: Shirley, I wrote for years without selling a single word. My monsters have done well for me. You think I'd give that up just so I could write about trees, or dogs, or daisies? Huhuh--Daisies! That's it, I'll write about my creatures who are pushing up the daisies. Your puritan upbringing holds you back from my monsters, but it certainly doesn't hurt your art of kissing.

question: That's life. My kisses are alive.
answer: Who's to say my monsters aren't alive? All of my books are based on fact, or legend. Thats perhaps why they're more interesting and sell in the top spots.

question: Well, fact or not, I don't see how we're going to find an ancient cemetery in these mountains tonight. I can't see a thing! Let's turn back.
answer: There's an old cemetery on this road. I've been there before.

question: I'm getting the jitters! Let's turn back!
answer: Okay. Just as soon as I find a place wide enough to turn around.

question: I'm so frightened.
answer: Well we certainly can't stay here. C'mon.

question: Where?
answer: In there.

question: It frightens me.
answer: Silly, there's nothing in there to be afraid of.

question: Then..then what's that music?
answer: That's what I want to find out. We have to get help.

question: What help can we possibly find in the cemetery at this time of night?
answer: Something's making that music.

question: I'm not sure I care to find out what it is.
answer: All right. Don't worry, I'll be right beside you.

question: What help will that do if something in there isn't dead?
answer: Not dead? In a cemetery?

question: I can't imagine anything dead playing that music.
answer: Well, it's probably just the caretaker, and that's exactly who we want to find. They'll have a telephone. C'mon.

question: Could it be some kind of college initiation?
answer: It's an initiation all right, but not of a college as you and I know them. Nothing alive looks like that!

question: Can't we get out of here?
answer: I'm not sure...

question: What do you mean?
answer: I'm not sure, myself. It's just a feeling I've had since the crash...Like I feel a cold chill all over.. ..Now this!

question: I'm so frightened.
answer: You've got a right to be. We're trapped by a bunch of fiends.

question: Those creatures..!
answer: Don't let them hear you.

question: What can we do?
answer: I don't know. I just don't know. But don't give up. We're not finished yet. Easy Shirley, Easy! Panic won't do us any good! Let me think. We've got to stall for time.

question: I'm afraid I'll faint.
answer: Whatever you do, don't do that.

question: HOLD! Let her continue to learn. The time is not yet right that they should join with us. ...And what is this?
answer: A symbol, Master.

question: What kind of symbol?
answer: She loved the bull ring and the matador. She danced to their destruction. Now she dances to her own destruction. Her dance is of skulls.

question: She came to us on the Day of the Dead.
answer: El Dia De Los Muertos...A celebration in her country.

question: Her dance has pleased me.
answer: With the loss of her lover, this one cast herself into the Volcano's fire.

question: She was?
answer: As I said, a worshipper of snakes, and of smoke, and flames.

question: Oh, yes, a religion of sorts.
answer: It would seem so, Master.

question: I don't like snakes. I remember the one Cleopatra used. Cute little rascal until it flicked out that red tongue, and those two sharp fangs. You'd never think such a little thing packed such a big wallop.
answer: Aaaaahhnnnhaaaaaannnhhh?

question: Hurt her? Hell, it killed her!
answer: Aaaahhhhnnnahhhnnnggnnn.

question: We had lots of snakes in my ancient Egypt...slimy, slinky things.
answer: Aahhhhnnnaaahahnn. AaaaaahhhhoooWWWOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!

question: When I was alive, they were the things nightmares were made of.
answer: Aaarrrgggaahh.

question: He wants us.
answer: Aaahhnnnahnnnn.

question: What do you suppose for?
answer: Aaaaannnnnuuunnnuhhhhh?

question: Did you do something to get us into trouble again?
answer: Aannnnaahhnn.

question: Did you howl off-key at the moon again?
answer: Aannnnaahhnn.

question: We better go before we make him mad. We are your servants, Master.
answer: Of course you are.

question: Have we in some way made you angry, Master?
answer: You know better than that.

question: We don't know of anything, Master...
answer: Then why do you shake so?

question: It's not often an Emperor like you calls on creatures like us.
answer: Well rest easy, I'm not angry with either of you.

question: Aaaahhhh. Then it is some service you desire of us.
answer: You are the keepers of the Damned. You two know them all. And I am tired of this usual type of entertainment. I want...a decided change.

question: You are the keepers of the Damned. You two know them all. And I am tired of this usual type of entertainment. I want...a decided change.
answer: The moon!...is soon gone! There is little time left for the remainder of the evening's pleasures.

question: Yes, yes yes I know all that.
answer: At the first sight of the morning sun's rays, we must be gone.

question: I suppose most of the others will have to wait for their judgement until after the next full moon.
answer: It would seem so, Master

question: The ropes are coming loose.
answer: Be careful!

question: I am--It's our only chance.
answer: Nothing is worth your life.

question: My guess is if we don't take the chance pretty soon, we're not going to have much life left anyway.
answer: I'm frightened. I'm so frightened.

question: Hold on just a little longer, Shirley.
answer: Be careful, oh please be careful. We'll never get out of here alive, I know it. I just feel it.

question: You do?
answer: Yes I feel it in my bones.

question: You're talking nonsense.
answer: Oh, no I'm not. These heathens probably have an open grave for us.

question: They wouldn't dare put us in the same grave-- or would they?
answer: I should hope not. I hate you!

question: That sudden?
answer: Yes, that sudden. If it weren't for you we wouldn't be hunting for an old cemetery on a night like this. It's all your fault.

question: Have you not enjoyed the evening's festivities? Ahh, that will soon change when you become one of us! It would seem that The Wolf Man would have you for his own! I have promised both The Wolf Man and The Mummy a reward. It could be that you are that reward. You need not worry...Not just now, anyway.
answer: Leave her alone, you fiend!

question: Fiend is it! You will not be so fortunate. Your existence will cease within moments. No one wishes to see a man dance... And you, my dear, will entertain for centuries to come.
answer: If I could get my hands on you...

question: ..Oh, You could do nothing! I can save you much pain.
answer: Leave her alone, I tell you!

question: I've got the ropes loose now. I've got my hands free. Be careful--Don't change your expression too much. They must not catch on.
answer: What can we do against them?

question: I don't know, yet. We'll just have to watch our chance. When it comes I'll know what to do--I hope I'll know what to do.
answer: I still don't know what ever made me go steady with a crackpot writer like you.

question: All right. Put it on heavy.
answer: My old boyfriend Tommy would never have gotten me in a mess like this. At least he's got brains.

question: Him! I'll bet he sleeps with all the lights on.
answer: Maybe so.

question: Well?
answer: Ahh, she will be yours.

question: When!?
answer: At your discretion...But first, I desire more entertainment.

question: The moon is almost gone!
answer: Ahh, there is yet time.

question: At the first sight of the morning's rays' light...
answer: I know the laws of the night. I state there is still time for yet another.

question: I would have time for my own pleasures!
answer: Your own pleasure comes only after mine, when I desire it. I am the Sole Ruler of the Dark World. There is no one to challenge my authority here. My word is the law--all powerful. No one is to challenge that authority, no one!. Is that understood? It is my command.

question: I understand, Master
answer: Then see that it does not happen again, in the penalty of Everlasting Despair. Now are there others?

question: There are others.
answer: Well then let us proceed.

question: The moon sinks lower into the hills! We must hurry to the finish.
answer: I will decide the conclusion.

question: You had the mummy cancel all the others scheduled for this session.
answer: Then cancel my order.

question: The moon is almost gone!
answer: There is yet time. Don't you want your own pleasure?

question: Oh, if there is only time!
answer: Hahh, there is always time... All in good time...there is always time. You shall have your pleasure. THAT... I decree

question: All others were but infinitessimal bits of fluff, compared to her This one would have died for feathers, furs, and fluff...and so she did!
answer: The time...is short.

question: For what!?!
answer: Your pleasures of course!

question: You mean...!
answer: You may take her now.

question: Is there time?
answer: You better hope there is.

question: Thank you, Master! Thank you.
answer: Now hurry, hurry. I will watch! Your desires may be my pleasure also...Our fitting climax to an evening's enter- tainment. You must...hurry now.
